captions.text:
Let's cut to the chase: How does the Higgs
field "give" particles mass? (and to be clear,

we're talking about the Higgs field and NOT
the Higgs Boson, which is merely an excitation

leftover after the process we're about to
explain. But I digress…back to mass!)

To begin, we need to know what we even mean
by "mass" - so we'll head the other direction

and talk about what it means to be massless:
This may sound crazy, but the defining feature

of any particle without mass is that it travels
at the speed of light. In fact, if we're honest

it should really be called the "speed of massless
particles," but since the first massless particles

we knew about were photons of light, the name
has stuck.

Anyway, the point is that all massless particles
travel 300 million meters every second. The

details of this are explained by special relativity,
but simply put, it's physically impossible

for a massless particle to NOT travel at 300
million meters per second. They can travel

in a straight line or bounce off of things
and change direction, but the speed of a massless
particle never changes.

And so mass is just the property of NOT HAVING
TO always travel at the speed of light. As

a side effect, this also means not being ABLE
to travel at the speed of light, but the key

is that particles with mass are lucky enough
that they get to travel at ANY speed they

want – as long as it's slower than light.
The amount of mass something has just tells

how hard it is for it to change from one of
these speeds to another.

Now, in Part I we mentioned that if there
were no Higgs field in the Standard Model,

ALL particles should be massless and thus
travel at the speed of light. But you and

I and swiss cheese clearly have mass, because
we have the beautiful luxury of being able
to sit still.

So how does the Higgs field help us do that?
Well, while massless particles can only travel

at the speed of light, they ARE allowed to
bounce off of things. Things like particles,

which are really just excitations in a quantum
field. For example, the electron field is

more concentrated at certain places called
"electrons" - and everywhere else is "empty

space". But the Higgs field is unusual in
that it has a high value EVERYWHERE – and

to be clear, this high value is NOT the famous
Higgs Boson - that's an extra excitation in

addition to this already elevated field. But
because the Higgs field has this everywhere

non-zero value, any particle that CAN interact
with it is pretty much bouncing off of it
all the time.

And if a massless particle bounces back and
forth and back and forth (or, since it's quantum

mechanics, does both at the same time), then
even though in between bounces it travels

at the speed of light, when you add everything
up it LOOKS like the particle is going slower

than light. Even... like it's not moving!
And since only things with mass are allowed

to not move, our massless particle now looks
and acts like it has mass. Well done, Higgs!

What's more, the Higgs field can even interact
with its own excitations, which is to say,

it can give mass to the Higgs Boson, too.
Actually, the Higgs field likes to interact

with itself so much more than with the lowly
electrons and protons that make us up, that

the Higgs Boson has a great deal more mass
– and that's part of why it's been so hard

to find. But we shouldn't complain, because
even though the Higgs has given us a lot of

trouble and only a little bit of mass, at
least we have mass, which allows us the simple
pleasure of not moving.

title: The Higgs Boson, Part II: What is Mass?

+electrocat1 The issue of defining mass in general relativity is also quite 
tricky. There are many competing definitions, which are useful for 
different things. However for our purposes we can think of measuring mass 
by using Kepler's laws, for instance: move far enough away from the black 
hole such that effects from general relativity are small, and from the 
distance and period you can calculate the mass. For this very special case 
this very simple definition is actually equivalent to some other more 
careful ways of defining mass, such as the Komar or ADM masses ( 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_in_general_relativity ).

Now a black hole is different from a  photon because it's not just a 
traveling, transversal wave like light is. It's a bunch of spacetime 
curvature held together by its own self-interaction -- they're closer to a 
proton or more precisely to a magnetic monopole in that sense. An easier 
example are KdV solitons, like in this video: watch?v=wEbYELtGZwI

Here you have a water wave held together by its own self interaction. 
Notice how it doesn't spread out over time, like a normal wave would. A 
black hole is a similar object. It's curvature held together by its own 
interactions and that curvature can be interpreted as a mass because when 
you move far enough away it generates the same effect that a massive 
material object would.

The correct generalization of photons to gravity, which are gravitons, are 
massless. Presumably. We've never seen one and we probably never will.

comments.text:
+Prabh Chahal It's not really easy to define the concept of "size" for 
elementary particles. Imagine a large box with one electron inside, and if 
you assume that box could perfectly seal the electron inside (there are no 
leaks). Now imagine you have some means of making the box's volume smaller, 
like a set of pistons or something. It turns out that you could keep doing 
this forever, making the volume as small as you wished, and the electron 
would still be there and behaving like an electron. People use this to say 
that the electron is a "point particle" and therefore has no size, and this 
is in principle valid for a photon too (even though the above experiment is 
impossible to do with a photon, even in principle, because photon number is 
not conserved). But in reality quantum objects do behave as if they had a 
"size", even if that is not the smallest object you could find them in. For 
the electron, one such useful measure of size is its Compton wavelength, 
which is defined as the wavelength of a photon whose energy corresponds to 
the electron's rest mass.

You can't really define a Compton wavelength for a photon though, since 
it's massless. As a result, we can have very large photons (of the order of 
hundreds of thousands of kilometers in wavelength, as in ELF), to very 
"small" photons like gamma rays.

comments.text:
+Red Ace "My problem is how they seem to postulate the existence of a field 
that exists everywhere in space"

Right, I think the problem you have there is with how the Higgs has been 
popularized. It is not exactly extraordinary from a particle physics point 
of view to postulate a field that permeates all of space: that is the case 
for every known particle! The photon is just a ripple on the photon field 
which permeates all of space. The electron is a ripple on the electron 
field which permeates all of space. And so on.

The only difference between the Higgs and these other particles is that the 
state of lowest energy of the Higgs field is one where it acquires a 
constant value everywhere in space, as opposed to the lowest state of say 
the photon field, which is zero everywhere in space. That is to say, adding 
an electric field to a region of space costs you energy, and removing the 
Higgs field costs you energy. That's the basic idea.

"If that's the case, then why postulate that this field is what causes it 
at all?  Why not just accept that there is no good explanation for the 
masses of particles at this time?"

Because without the Higgs (or some mechanism like technicolor which in 
effect accomplishes the same thing in a different manner) you cannot have 
massive elementary particles *at all*. The weak interaction has a crucial 
feature: it sees particles of positive helicity (spin in the same direction 
as their momentum) differently than particles of negative helicity (spin in 
the opposite direction as their momentum). If particles are massive, you 
can move to a reference frame where their momentum points in the opposite 
direction and flip their helicity by coordinate transformation. Major no-no 
for the theory. On the other hand, if the fundamental particle is massless, 
you can't ever flip its momentum by coordinate transformation and helicity 
becomes a good quantity. A mass given by Higgs (or technicolor) is still 
okay, but a particle simply having a mass by itself is not.

Worse, electroweak theory doesn't even make sense without a Higgs because 
the W and Z bosons are massive. The gauge symmetry that *defines* the 
theory requires them to be massless much like the photon. Spontaneous 
symmetry breaking is the only way out that we know of, and if such a 
mechanism weren't found our understanding of these things would be shown to 
be deeply flawed. We'd pretty much have to toss the entire thing away and 
start over.

comments.text:
+Ron Maimon Your picture is compelling, but I don't think I like it. Here's 
my reasons:

1. Consider scattering between momentum eigenstates. Being completely 
delocalized, there is no "returning wind" --  an emitted force carrier can 
be reabsorbed at any point in space. And yet, the attractiveness or 
repulsiveness of the interaction is unchanged in this picture, as long as 
you define "attractive" in terms of the direction of momentum transfer.

2. Imagine you have quark antiquark annihilation producing gluons. Or if 
you don't want to worry about all the nonperturbative crap you can also 
imagine you're a physicist driven mad from working too many years on N=4 
super YM and you decide to use a nonlinear gauge condition in ordinary QED. 
What you would fin then is that Feynman diagrams involving only physical 
particles give you unphysical answers, including loss of transversality and 
unitarity. As you know, you must include ghosts to get a consistent 
description. Since ghosts can't be real particles, the picture you 
described runs into trouble with gauge invariance.

3. You don't even have to invoke gauge invariance to see that Feynman 
diagrams have many strange properties. This is very clear in the many body 
problem. Some fermion diagrams violate the exclusion principle (c.f. 
Mattuck page 74). Bubble diagrams seem even weirder. Of course that this 
means really is that while the S-matrix is perfectly nice and physical, its 
decomposition in Feynman diagrams is in general not. Speaking of Mattuck, 
my approach to the subject is similar to his: I talk about the diagrams as 
if they were physical because it's convenient, but I constantly remind 
myself not to read too much into them.

4. Let's imagine that in a parallel universe Maxwell had miraculously 
discovered functional integrals before anyone had any idea about quantum 
mechanics. He would then just write down in Euclidean space (schematically 
because youtube isn't conducive to writing equations)

Z = (path integral) e^(-S/a)

Where "a" is just a parameter that he would take to zero at the end of the 
calculation (i.e., take the classical limit). He might then do the usual 
stuff and get Feynman rules, with the additional prescription that only 
tree level diagrams are to be kept. What you find then is a perfectly 
reasonable (if of dubious utility) description of classical E&M.

You can in principle do the same to other field theories and find the same 
relationship between the spin of the force carrier and the 
attractiveness/repulsiveness of the interaction without mentioning quantum 
mechanics or self energies at all.

5. This mixing between tree level and one loop doesn't appear 
perturbatively consistent, and happens differently in different situations. 
The free theory example makes this very clear: the self interactions in the 
classical sources are at tree level (indeed they must be since they 
correspond to the classical self energies in E&M, all "quantumness" is 
encoded in the functional determinant), but they're one loop when 
considering scattering between asymptotic states in an interacting theory. 
It seems to me that what your picture is actually describing is screening, 
as is the usual interpretation of the self energies.

6. There's been a lot of recent progress in this direction. I'll cite two 
lines of work.

People like Dunne and Ünsal have been discussing the application of 
resurgence to perturbation theory. The main idea is that to recover Borel 
summability of higher orders in perturbation theory, low order 
nonperturbative saddle points must be included. Or, to flip that upside 
down, high orders in perturbation theory somehow encode nonperturbative 
physics. This seems to defy any simple explanation of Feynman diagrams as 
being physical processes and adds evidence to the idea that they're 
convenient ways of expressing contributions to physical amplitudes.

The now famous work on amplitude calculations by people like Nima 
Arkani-Hamed, Zvi Bern and the like shows that there is a compelling 
physical picture behind amplitude calculations (to all orders) at least in 
certain conformally invariant theories. This is a rapidly moving field and 
I'll refrain from speculating *too* much about what we will learn on the 
whole, but at least for N=4 super Yang-Mills it seems that Feynman diagrams 
are very clunky and opaque when compared to the techniques they've 
developed.

(end list)

That being said however there is a definite way to calculate forces in 
terms of virtual particles that is very physical at least at tree level. I 
will not reproduce the argument in detail here since it's a bit long but 
you can look at Baez's masterful exposition. To summarize, the crucial 
ingredient that the ordinary pinball description misses is the uncertainty 
principle. One ingredient of your description is still there -- the 
attractiveness or repulsiveness of the interaction is dictated by the 
superposition of the photon "momentum space wavefunction" (really the 
amplitude for momentum transfer due to a single photon) with the 
unperturbed "electron" wavefunction. 

I must emphasize that this is still classical physics, just in a language 
more appropriate to scattering experiments than static force computations. 
"Uncertainty principle" sounds quantumy but here it's just a property of 
Fourier transforms. We're doing classical field theory with Bizarro 
Maxwell's formalism, that's all.

classify long posts containing links as spam.

I agree with everything you said about the video and Higgs mechanism, but 
you misidentified the problem in the popularizations of Feynman.

The complaint you give: "naively, Feynman particle exchange is always 
repelling" is resolved when you understand that the loop-expansion in the 
perturbation series is acausal, meaning that it requires the whole history 
to resolve. If you look in any decent Hamiltonian picture, you can't say 
"the particle emitted a photon which is intended to only be absorbed by the 
second particle", because photons don't come with a label. For all you know 
that photon is going right back to the first particle which emitted it, in 
which case it would be part of the mass-renormalization and wave-function 
renormalization for the original particle, rather than producing a force. 
The force-producing things are just a little bit of perturbation on top of 
the ultraviolet divergent self-interaction.

So when you are telling a Feynman story which pretends to be causal, you 
need to say "the particle emits a bunch of virtual photons at an amplitude 
proportional to its charge", and then these particles quantumly 
random-walk, most of these photons go out and come right back to the 
particle that emitted them, especially the ones that don't wander about too 
long, the contributions with short Schwinger parameters.

When you put another particle there, and it has opposite charge, you get 
that some of the particles can go from particle A and get absorbed by 
particle B, so never getting a chance to reimpact A, and this leads to a 
net attraction, if you like from the "Lesage wind" of returning particles 
on particle A, which is lessened because the ones that ended up on B.

When the charges are the same, the interference properties make it that the 
process of emission and absorption leads to a net repulsion, because the 
ones going back an forth make an opposite sign contribution for the return 
amplitude. You can think of it as saying that the ones going from one to 
the other are destructively deleted as compared to the ones that go out 
toward the other particle and come right back.

This intuition is omitted from all books, even though it makes both 
attraction and repulsion intuitively comprehensible. Aside from authors not 
knowing about it, I think that the reason is because it isn't compatible 
with the Feynman loop series expansion. The process of emitting and 
absorbing the same photon is one-loop, while the classical 
repulsion/absorption is tree level. The description I gave you above mixes 
them up, when the contributions are separted in order. The reason you do 
need to mix them up to understand the processes is because loop counting is 
over the entire history, you need to know what happens to every photon to 
count loop order.

So at the end, when you do this acausal Feynman/Stueckelberg loop-order 
thing to describe field theory with particles, you end up reproducing 
attraction and repulsion at tree level, but it is only so because these 
tree-level things are embedded in a broader theory which inclues loop level 
events.

To see that what I am saying is actually true,  consider a free field 
coupled to a classical source, so free E&M coupled to classical currents, 
or a scalar field coupled to a scalar source. The same repulsion paradox 
applies to these sourced free-fields, you can make the same argument that 
the classical sources must always repel (or attract). But this is trivially 
exactly solvable, and the energy times the total time is J(x) J(y)K(x-y) 
integrated over all x,y where K is the propagator. When J is the sum of two 
delta-sources localized at position a and b for all time, you get the net 
attraction/repulsion force K(a-b,t) integrated over all time t. This 
represents the particles going from a to b, and gives you both attraction 
and repulsion forces, depending on the signs of the coupling.

But you see that you threw away the back-and-forth contribution: 
J(a)J(a)K(a-a,t) and J(b)J(b)K(b-b,t) parts, which are the (divergent for a 
point source) self-energy of the source. The resulting repulsion or 
attraction is always relative to the base-point energy of the returning 
contribution, and it can be bigger or smaller, according to the sign, so 
there is no paradox in either sign for the energy or the force. Then it is 
obvious that the potential energy is due to particles emitted by source A 
and absorbed by source A, particles emitted by source B and absorbed by 
source B (both divergent energy contributions you need to subtract out) and 
finally particles emitted by A and absorbed by B, which depending on how 
they interfere with the self-absorbed particles, produce repulsion or 
attraction, if you like depending on which way their perturbation alters 
the "gust of returning particles" on the sources (but only if you imagine 
the particles have momentum, and not position, so not in a 
Feynman/Schwinger path picture).

This picture is now completely accurate, but it mixes up tree and loop 
level mathematically, because the returning photons are loop level, and the 
classical interaction are tree. So while there really is no problem with 
understanding attractions intuitively in the Feynman picture (attraction is 
actually more intuitive than repulsions), it is not compatible with the 
mathematically convenient factorization of the  S-matrix diagrams into a 
loop series.

For sure the billiard ball picture is inaccurate, because it is classical, 
it makes the billiard balls look ballistic, with both position an 
momentum.  The net force is the gradient of the net energy, not the 
ballistic returning momentum, but it can be considered as a suitable 
average of returning momentum if you do an old-fasioned perturbation 
series, pre Feynman, where you quantize the field in k-modes and sum over 
these.
